unnormalised: Okay, so you know how managing schedules in the office can sometimes feel like herding cats, especially with everyone's personal commitments and the constant stream of meetings? Well, let’s talk about how we actually make it work, or at least, *try* to make it work.
normalised: Okay, so you know how managing schedules in the office can sometimes feel like herding cats, especially with everyone's personal commitments and the constant stream of meetings? Well, let’s talk about how we actually make it work, or at least, try to make it work.

unnormalised: First off, there's the whole thing with trying to find a time that *everyone* is free. It's almost a mythical quest. You ping a few colleagues – Priya, Rakesh, and Aisha – about a project kickoff meeting. Priya's got her dance class every Tuesday at 6:00 PM IST. Rakesh has a doctor's appointment on 10/10/2024 in the afternoon. Aisha’s already booked for a client call on Wed at 11 AM. And then you, of course, have your own commitments!
normalised: First off, there's the whole thing with trying to find a time that everyone is free. It's almost a mythical quest. You ping a few colleagues – Priya, Rakesh, and Aisha – about a project kickoff meeting. Priya's got her dance class every Tuesday at six zero zero P-M I-S-T. Rakesh has a doctor's appointment on tenth October two thousand and twenty four in the afternoon. Aisha’s already booked for a client call on Wednesday at eleven A-M. And then you, of course, have your own commitments!

unnormalised: Then comes the confusion about time zones. We have teams spread across Mumbai, Delhi, and even some folks working remotely from the US. Setting up a call at 2:00 PM IST might mean someone on the West Coast has to join at 4:30 AM PST. Not ideal, right? We try to be mindful, but sometimes, deadlines are deadlines. I once accidentally scheduled a meeting for the team at 3:30 am because I forgot to convert the timings.
normalised: Then comes the confusion about time zones. We have teams spread across Mumbai, Delhi, and even some folks working remotely from the U-S. Setting up a call at two zero zero P-M I-S-T might mean someone on the West Coast has to join at four thirty A-M P-S-T. Not ideal, right? We try to be mindful, but sometimes, deadlines are deadlines. I once accidentally scheduled a meeting for the team at three thirty am because I forgot to convert the timings.

unnormalised: Let's not forget the joys of public holidays. Suddenly, 15/08/2024 (Independence Day) rolls around, and half the team is off celebrating. Trying to get anything done that week feels like swimming upstream. And there are so many festivals in India. You have Diwali, Eid, Holi, Christmas and so many regional ones. So, finding common working hours is a big task.

So, finding common working hours is a big task.

unnormalised: The rise of remote work has also thrown a spanner in the works. While the flexibility is great, it can make scheduling a bit more challenging. People might be juggling childcare responsibilities, elder care, or simply working different hours to suit their lifestyle. It's become more about deliverables and less about face-to-face hours, which, honestly, isn’t a bad thing.

unnormalised: So, what’s the secret sauce? Honestly, there isn’t one. But a few things do help. Using shared calendars like Google Calendar or Outlook Calendar is a lifesaver. Clear communication is key – be upfront about your availability and any constraints you might have. Polls, doodle polls etc. can also help. And a healthy dose of flexibility and understanding goes a long way.

unnormalised: In the end, office scheduling is a bit of a balancing act. It's about finding the sweet spot where everyone can contribute effectively, without sacrificing their personal well-being. It takes effort, patience, and a willingness to compromise. And maybe, just maybe, a bit of luck!
